content.title: Parkinson Disease
content.summary: Parkinson disease (PD) is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder caused by loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta. It presents with the cardinal motor features of bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, and postural instability, along with numerous non-motor symptoms. Treatment centers on dopamine replacement therapy.
key_points: Cardinal features: Bradykinesia (required) + rest tremor, rigidity, or postural instability
Pathology: Loss of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra; Lewy bodies with α-synuclein
Asymmetric onset is typical and supports diagnosis
Non-motor symptoms: REM sleep behavior disorder, anosmia, constipation, depression
Levodopa/carbidopa is most effective treatment; start when functionally impaired
Motor complications (wearing off, dyskinesias) develop after 5-10 years of levodopa
content.statement: Parkinson disease is a progressive dopaminergic neurodegenerative disorder presenting with bradykinesia and other motor/non-motor features, managed with dopamine replacement therapy while addressing motor complications.

explanation.intuition: Think of the brain's motor system as an orchestra where dopamine is the conductor. In Parkinson's, the conductor (dopamine-producing cells) gradually dies, causing the orchestra to play slowly (bradykinesia), stiffly (rigidity), and shakily (tremor). Levodopa temporarily provides a substitute conductor, but over time the remaining musicians become less responsive.
explanation.key_insight: BRADYKINESIA must be present for diagnosis - it's not just slowness but progressive reduction in amplitude and speed with repetitive movements (decrement). A patient with only tremor does NOT have Parkinson disease. Also, response to levodopa is supportive of diagnosis; poor response suggests parkinsonism-plus syndrome.
explanation.technical_details: Symptoms appear when 60-80% of striatal dopamine is lost. Direct pathway (D1) promotes movement; indirect pathway (D2) inhibits. Dopamine loss causes indirect pathway overactivity. α-synuclein aggregates form Lewy bodies and spread in a prion-like manner (Braak staging).

definitions_glossary.Parkinson_disease: Progressive neurodegenerative disorder with dopaminergic loss causing motor and non-motor symptoms
definitions_glossary.bradykinesia: Slowness and decreasing amplitude of repetitive movements; REQUIRED for diagnosis
definitions_glossary.rigidity: Increased resistance to passive movement; cogwheel if superimposed tremor
definitions_glossary.resting_tremor: 4-6 Hz 'pill-rolling' tremor present at rest, suppressed with action
definitions_glossary.postural_instability: Impaired balance; occurs later in disease; pull test positive
definitions_glossary.substantia_nigra: Midbrain structure containing dopaminergic neurons; degenerates in PD
definitions_glossary.alpha_synuclein: Protein that misfolds and aggregates in PD and related synucleinopathies
definitions_glossary.wearing_off: Levodopa effect duration shortens over time; end-of-dose deterioration
definitions_glossary.dyskinesia: Involuntary choreiform movements from peak levodopa levels
definitions_glossary.on_off_fluctuations: Unpredictable motor state changes in advanced PD
definitions_glossary.DBS: Deep brain stimulation - surgical treatment for motor fluctuations/dyskinesias

pathophysiology.mechanism: Progressive degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in substantia nigra pars compacta with α-synuclein accumulation, leading to striatal dopamine deficiency and basal ganglia circuit dysfunction

Braak_staging.stage_1_2: Medulla, olfactory bulb (prodromal: constipation, anosmia, RBD)

genetics.LRRK2: Most common autosomal dominant; late onset

supportive_features: Clear and sustained response to levodopa

differential_diagnosis: Essential tremor (action tremor, bilateral, positive family history)
Progressive supranuclear palsy (early falls, vertical gaze palsy)
Multiple system atrophy (early autonomic failure, cerebellar signs)
Dementia with Lewy bodies (early dementia, visual hallucinations)

dopaminergic.levodopa_carbidopa: Most effective; start when functional impairment; risk of motor complications
dopaminergic.dopamine_agonists: Pramipexole, ropinirole; may delay motor complications but impulse control disorders
dopaminergic.MAO_B_inhibitors: Selegiline, rasagiline; mild symptomatic benefit; may be neuroprotective

motor_complications.wearing_off: Add COMT inhibitor, MAO-B inhibitor, or increase levodopa frequency
motor_complications.dyskinesias: Reduce individual levodopa doses; add amantadine

surgical.DBS: Subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus interna; for motor fluctuations refractory to medications
surgical.candidate: Good levodopa response, no dementia, age <70 typically

definition.@value: A progressive neurodegenerative movement disorder caused by loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra, characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, rest tremor, and postural instability

scopeNote.@value: Covers pathophysiology, diagnosis, and treatment of idiopathic Parkinson disease

learning_objectives: Define cardinal motor features of Parkinson disease with bradykinesia as essential
Describe the pathophysiology involving substantia nigra dopaminergic loss
Recognize red flags suggesting parkinsonism-plus syndromes
Compare dopaminergic treatment options and their complications
Identify candidates for deep brain stimulation
clinical_pearls: Asymmetric onset strongly supports PD vs other parkinsonism
RBD may precede motor symptoms by 10+ years (prodromal PD)
Levodopa: best efficacy but motor complications after 5-10 years
Early falls, poor levodopa response = think parkinsonism-plus syndrome
common_misconceptions: Tremor is required for diagnosis - bradykinesia is required, tremor is not
Starting levodopa early causes faster motor complications - timing less important than dose
DBS cures Parkinson's - it manages symptoms, disease still progresses
